DR. KELLY'S RADIUM CLINIC

JOHN DREW FOR HULLABALOO

SPEER TO SPEAK TO STUDENTS CARLISLE OVERWHELMS HOPKINS

Plans as Yet in Abeyance — To Be
"Free as the Wind" - Up to

The medical world was recently
quite startled by the announcement
that Dr. Howard A. Kelly would
endeavor to establish a free radium
clinic for the treatment of cancerous
and kindred diseases. As Dr. Kelly
is a Baltimorean, and professor of
gynecology in the University, this
news is of esix:cial interest to Hopkins people, especially, as Dr. Kelly
has said that he would endeavor to
make his free clinic an integral part
of the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
This news comes as a fitting climax
to one of the greatest discoveries in
medical science, the discovery of
radium as a cure for cancer, which
has been heretofore considered an
unconquerable di.ease. It can also
be used as a certain cure for tumors
and the like. The unfortunate part
of it, however, is the extreme cost
of radium, which is now the most
precious substance in the world.
The price is now ninety dollars a
milligram (about one-sixteen thousandth of an ounce) and steadily
rising, due to the great demand for
it, as nearly every hospital and
medical school in the world is
eagerly trying to obtain some small
amount of this wonderful cure.
Dr. Kelly has said that the plans
for the clinic are rather in abeyance
just at present, but that the only
thing necessary is the acquisition of
a sufficient amount of radium. He
added that at present he possesses
one gram of the precious material,
and soon hopes to acquire a few
more grams, in order to expedite
the formation of the clinic. This
clinic will be free to all who are
unable to pay, "free as the wind,"
Dr. Kelly says, and will be an inestimable boon to humanity, as it
will be the wily one of its kind in
the world. Dr. Kelly himself is
the moving spirit in this enterprise,
being aided by Dr. Douglas, of New
York, who is connected with the
Phelps-Dodge Mining Company,
one of the largest concerns in the
world. As to the establishment of
the clinic in connection with the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, Dr. Kelly
says the matter is entirely up to
the trustees of the Hospital and of
the University. As the Johns Hopkins University has always been to
the fore in the advancement of
medical science, it is expected that
advantage will be taken of such an
unparalleled opportunity to continue
its great work.

The senior class, in order to
finance its "Hullabaloo, has secured
a benefit at Ford's on next Monday
night, November 17. John Drew,
the noted American comedian, will
appear for the first time in Baltimore in his latest comedy hits,"The
Will" and "The Tyranny of Tears."
The "Hullabaloo" Board is most
anxious that all Hopkins men buy
tickets for this benefit; for the
money received from this source
helps very materially in the publication of the "Hullabaloo. Tickets
may be obtained from any member
of the senior class, or from the
University postoffice. The management has also sent out a large number of tickets among the faculty, the
alumni, the graduate students, and
the friends of the University. If
anyone has received tickets, and has
not returned his money, the "Hullabaloo" Board urges that he do so
at once.
The following is a short description of this splendid bill:
, The distinguished American comedian, John Drew, appears for the
first time in Baltimore in his latest
comedy triumphs that are now being
successfully produced at the Empire
Theatre in New York. Mr. Drew
and his company come direct from
New York to Ford's.
In all his career Mr. Drew has
never had a fuller or a finer program than this present double bill.
"The Will" is a new work by the
recently-knighted J. M. Barrie, the
author of "The Little Minister,"
"Peter Pan," and "What Every
Woman Knows." "The Tyranny of
Tears" is a superbly modern comedy
by C. Haddon Chambers. These
exceptional plays will delight all
lovers of the highest dramatic art,
and in the leading roles Mr. Drew's
artistic charm and magnetism have
never been more appealing.
Both plays are exceedingly attractive, and superbly interpreted
by the New York company, including Julian L'Estrange, Mary Boland, Frank Kemble Cooper, Laura
Hope Crews, Herbert Druce, Murray Ross and others. Mr. Drew
is under the management of Charles
Frohman, and both plays are produced under the stage direction of
William Seymour.
Dr. French—What are the three
most used words in this school?
Preshie—I don't know.
Dr. French—Correct; sit down!

During the week of November 9
to 16,the First Presbyterian Church,
Park avenue and Madison street,
commemorates the 150th anniversary of its founding. Services will
be held on November II and 12,
but the service of most interest to
students will be held at three o'clock
Sunday, November 16. At this
service Dr. Robert E. Speer will
speak.
This service is primarily for the
collegiate students of Baltimore. A
group of Johns Hopkins men will
lead the singing, and Dean Griffin
of this University and Dr. Hiram
Woods of the University of Maryland will preside at the service. Dr.
Barr, the minister of the church,
extends through THE NEws-LETTER a personal invitation to every
Hopkins man to attend this service.
Dr. Speer is recognized in the
Orient and throughout the countries
of Europe, as well as in America,
as probably the leader in the modern field of Christian work and endeavor. He received his A.B. at
Princeton, '89, and was a classmate
and comrade of Dr. Barr. He made
at Princeton, it is said, a higher
average than any man since Aaron
Burr, and at the same time played
end on the football team.
It is interesting to note that Dr.
Speer is the fifth layman, not a
minister, to be granted the degree of doctor of divinity by the
University of Edinburgh. The
fourth was Prince Bismarck, the
famous Chancellor of Germany.
Francis L. Patton, D.D., LL.D.,
preceded President Woodrow Wilson as the president of Princeton
University. He is in charge of the
Theological Seminary at Princeton,
and, says Dr. Barr, cis recognized
as one of the keenest minds at work
today in facing the intellectual problems arising in the student world."

Playing like a whirlwind from
start to finish, the Carlisle Indians
overwhelmed Hopkins Saturday by
sheer superiority; the final score
being 61 to o. The Black and Blue
put up a hard fight, but was unable
to withstand the massed charging
of the heavy Indian backs, or to
break down their solid interference.
The red men played like a well oiled
machine, and seemed to be able to
gain whatever they wanted throughout the contest.
Branham played a beautiful game
for.Hopkins; his tackling was sure
and hard, and whenever he received
the ball on the kickoff, he tore like
a streak through the line of oncoming Indians, advancing the ball
remarkably far. Captain Leibensperger was most aggressive. Tippett
and Fulton also did star playing.
The Indians scored first after
about three minutes of play. After
the kickoff, Wilkins9p to Calac,
the Indians madt--firs-vdown on the
two-line plays, and then advanced
the ball steadily, Calac doing most
of the gaining, until, by a perfect
forward pass, they got it to the fiveyard line. Then they fumbled, but
Garlow quickly recovered the ball.
Hopkins held for one play, but on
the next, Calac carried the ball over.
Garlow missed goal. Score, 6 to 0.
Wilkinson kicked off to Bracklin,
and Carlisle took the ball steadily
up the field to the 20-yard line,
whence, by three well executed
double passes, Calac again carried
the ball over. Guyon kicked.
At the next kickoff the quarter
ended. During the next period the
Indians crossed the goal twice, Guyon kicking successfull both times.
The double pass was used by Carlisle to great advantage in gaining
these touchdowns.

Last Thursday Henry E. Corner, '14, was chosen president, and
William A. Baker, '15, secretary, at
the election of Student Council
officers. Some little time was spent
in important discussion.
The unconstitutional election of
"Tom" Troxell as one of the delegates from the junior class was
under consideration.
As Troxell is a member of the
Athletic Board, a circumstance
which precludes his holding a position on the Student Council, the
Council was forced to ask for the
election of another delegate from
the Class of 1915. A new election
will be held by the junior class this
week.
The Student Council called a
meeting of non-fraternity men last
week, in order to hold an election
of the non-fraternity representative
on the Cotillon Board. From among
the three nominees, Baker, Geissel
and Supplee, William A. Baker was
chosen.

G. NI. Janes, Ph.D. '13, is associate in economies at the University
of Washington in Seattle.
F. T. Stockton, Ph.D. 'ii, formerly instructor of economics at the
University of Rochester, is now assistant professor of economics at the
University of Indiana.
R. C. McCabe, A.B. 'ii, who was
at the University of Maryland Law
School last year, is now in New
York with the American Telegraph
and Telephone Company.
Noble Stockett, A.B. 'II, is back
at the University to take up graduate work in political economy.
Stockett taught last year at the Kent
School.
T. W. Glocker, Ph.D. '07, at one
time instructor in economics at
Washington University, is now head
of the Department of Economics
and Sociology at the University of
Tennessee.
Dr. N. R. Whitney, Ph.D. '13,
instructor in economics, will deliver
during 1913-14 a course of weekly
lectures on "Money and Banking"
before the Baltimore Chapter of the
American Institute of Bankers.
A. M. Sakolski, Ph.D. '05, is the
author of a new book: "American
Railroad Economics," published by
McMillan. He is an instructor in
railroad finance at the New York
University School of Commerce?
Accounts and Finance.
Four of the members of the first
year class at the University of
Maryland Law School are Hopkins
men: P. 0. Carter, A.B. '13; 0. K.
Schmied, A.B. '13, who is also
teaching modern languages at the
Baltimore City College; R. H.
Woods, A.B. '435, and J. B. Brinton,
ex-'i6, who in addition to his law
course, is in the claim department
of the Maryland Casualty Company.
Other Hopkins men at the Law
School are: J. K. Burgan, A.B. '12
W. L. Clark, A.B. '93; M. W.
Rosenfeld, A.B. '12, and Lindsay
Rogers, A.R. '12.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 10, 1913.
1914 Hullabaloo.

In considering the amount of
money, time and work required for
the production of the modern classbook, one sometimes feels that the
game is not worth the candle. It
is true that the appeal of the college
annual is limited to a small sphere,
and within that sphere is varying
force; but it is from a no larger
number of persons that the money
and work comes, and for them it is
a very worth while sacrifice. How
many men have wished they had a
record of their years between boy
and man—of all the times of life in
many ways the most definitive and
--reminiscentially interesting. The
class-book is a permanent and artistic memento in word and picture
of the happenings and surroundings of a detached but crowded four
years, which otherw'ise too often
blur in later memory to a phantasmagoria of traditional "college life"
—a far, far cry from the real.
The fact remains that the creation
of a book is a long, hard job—to get
the material, to discover some original way of molding what tends to
assume the most conventional of
forms, to raise the wherewithal. In
this last everyone can help. Especially at Hopkins is it true that the
task cannot be turned over to a
board and forgotten. We have
neither the pull of West Point or
Annapolis, nor the multitudinous
student 1?ody of Harvard or Michigan to make the advertisement-hunt
a primrose path to easy financing.
Nor are our classes large enough
fo.: pocket-digging to produce great
treasure. The "Hullabaloo" needs
and expects a general manifestation
of supporting school-spirit (to use
a much-tortured term legitimately).
If anyone has a peculiar chance to
land an "ad" for the book, do it
without grubbing for commission—
every member of the Board does a
hundred times the work without re-

turn. Give preference to those
whose cards on the basement wall
show their faith in your willingness
to favor "Hullabaloo" advertisers.
When there is a theatre benefit, buy
the best seat you can, and see that
your family and friends go too.
The show selected will reward your
time both in value and interest.
Of course, buy a copy when the
issue of the book appears.
The 1914 "Hullabaloo" either will
do no discredit to the University
(and for that it must at least repay
the purchase price), or it will not
be published—and it is already too
far advanced for apprehension on
that score.

The Annual Disaster.

Every convenience that people
have must be paid for in some way
or other, and it seems that the use
of the University elevator may soon
be paid for by physical injury to
some of the many who patronize it
daily. On Wednesday of last week
the car dropped from the first floor
to the bottom of the shaft—an annual occurrence. It is fortunate that
none of the passengers were hurt,
yet a drop from the third or fourth
floor would undoubtedly result in
a wrecked car and broken bones.
The service on the elevator is admittedly poor, either because the
operator is unskilled, or because the
car does not obey the lever. There
are frequent stops midway between
floors when the elevator has overrun its scheduled station. When
upward bound this results merely
in delay and often in a mad rush
of students down the corridors and
a dash into a lecture-room after the
roll has been taken. But when the
elevator fails to stop on its downward course, the passengers find
their hearts in their throats for fear
of the annual disaster. The "freshmen have no fear," for they may
not ride; but a general boycott of
this invidious elevator might effect its safety more so than does the
city inspector.

Freshmen Athletic Activities.

About forty freshmen, who made
the much coveted 500 in strength
tests, have been put in an advanced
class by Director Kistler. The class
meets twice weekly and has been
divided into four sections under
captains. There will be basket-ball
games and track meets.
Mr. Kistler had the four sections
running through their paces in the
"cage" last Tuesday and there is
evidence of some first-class track
material in the new men.
Mr. Kemper Simpson allowed it
to transpire last week that a young
lady had proposed to him during the
summer. Good luck to her!

The Johns Hopkins Chess Club
will hold its reorganization meeting
next Thursday, November 13, at
P. M. in the chapel. All those
who are interested in chess or wish
to learn the game, particularly
freshmen, are invited to this meeting. Officers will be elected for the
year.
The question of a return match
with the Chess Club of the University of Georgetown will be considered. It will be remembered
that we sent a team to Washington
last spring, consisting of seven
men, and that in a very hotly contested set of games, we came out
the victors by the score of 8 to 6.
It is our turn, now, to challenge
Georgetown to a match in this city,
which will be done as soon as possible. All prospective candidates
for the team are asked to attend
the meeting.

The singers and players of the
University are making good use of
the time before the concert season
opens. The first public performance is scheduled for Thursday, December 4, at Relay, Md. This will
be a sort of preliminary concert, intended more to give the Clubs a
good try-out before the Christmas
trip than to "rake in the coin." It
has not yet been decided what towns
will be inflicted with Hopkins music
during the holidays, but the managers are at work, and an attractive
schedule should be the result. Some
of the older men are suggesting
that the musicians do not try to do
up everything in one or two trips.
Several of the older men know from
experience that a trip of more than
two concerts becomes monotonous,
while if there are six or seven trips
interspersed throughout the year,
everybody can enjoy them more.
The manager of the Clubs is always ready to receive the three-dollar assessment fee.
The Glee Club held its usual three
rehearsals. The tenors are making
fine progress, and the second bassos
are also doing good work. The first
bassos, however, seem a little backward. There are about twenty men
in this "first-base squad," a number
of whom will have to be weeded out
before concert time. The Instrumental Club is, holding its practices
on Saturday mornings at 9.30. This
is done in order to enable the men
from the Medical School to attend.
The "Meds" are sending two mandolins and a pianist as their representatives. Leader Geissel is ready
to welcome any player of mandolin,
guitar, 'cello, and especially violin,
next Saturday morning. The regular meetings of the Clubs may be
found on the Calendar.

Harry N. Holmes, Ph.D.'07, who
is now teaching at Earlham College,

which he hopes will be used in the
various games. It is an Earlham
College yell invented by Dr. Holmes,
which he has adapted for Hopkins
use. It goes:
Beat St. John's! Beat St. John's!
Beat 'em! Beat 'em! Beat 'em!
Beat St. John's! Beat St. John's!
Eat 'em up! Eat 'em up! HOPKINS!
In yelling it, the accent comes on
"beat," in all the first three lines
on "John's" in the first and third,
and on "up" in the fourth.

to the community.

Historical Development of Engineering." The speakers were given
a vote of thanks at the conclusion
of the meeting.

Men Through the News -Letter.

The medical world was recently
quite startled by the announcement
that Dr. Howard A. Kelly would
endeavor to establish a free radium
clinic for the treatment of cancerous
and kindred diseases. As Dr. Kelly
is a Baltimorean, and professor of
gynecology in the University, this
news is of esix:cial interest to Hopkins people, especially, as Dr. Kelly
has said that he would endeavor to
make his free clinic an integral part
of the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
This news comes as a fitting climax
to one of the greatest discoveries in
medical science, the discovery of
radium as a cure for cancer, which
has been heretofore considered an
unconquerable di.ease. It can also
be used as a certain cure for tumors
and the like. The unfortunate part
of it, however, is the extreme cost
of radium, which is now the most
precious substance in the world.
The price is now ninety dollars a
milligram (about one-sixteen thousandth of an ounce) and steadily
rising, due to the great demand for
it, as nearly every hospital and
medical school in the world is
eagerly trying to obtain some small
amount of this wonderful cure.
Dr. Kelly has said that the plans
for the clinic are rather in abeyance
just at present, but that the only
thing necessary is the acquisition of
a sufficient amount of radium. He
added that at present he possesses
one gram of the precious material,
and soon hopes to acquire a few
more grams, in order to expedite
the formation of the clinic. This
clinic will be free to all who are
unable to pay, "free as the wind,"
Dr. Kelly says, and will be an inestimable boon to humanity, as it
will be the wily one of its kind in
the world. Dr. Kelly himself is
the moving spirit in this enterprise,
being aided by Dr. Douglas, of New
York, who is connected with the
Phelps-Dodge Mining Company,
one of the largest concerns in the
world. As to the establishment of
the clinic in connection with the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, Dr. Kelly
says the matter is entirely up to
the trustees of the Hospital and of
the University. As the Johns Hopkins University has always been to
the fore in the advancement of
medical science, it is expected that
advantage will be taken of such an
unparalleled opportunity to continue
its great work.

The senior class, in order to
finance its "Hullabaloo, has secured
a benefit at Ford's on next Monday
night, November 17. John Drew,
the noted American comedian, will
appear for the first time in Baltimore in his latest comedy hits,"The
Will" and "The Tyranny of Tears."
The "Hullabaloo" Board is most
anxious that all Hopkins men buy
tickets for this benefit; for the
money received from this source
helps very materially in the publication of the "Hullabaloo. Tickets
may be obtained from any member
of the senior class, or from the
University postoffice. The management has also sent out a large number of tickets among the faculty, the
alumni, the graduate students, and
the friends of the University. If
anyone has received tickets, and has
not returned his money, the "Hullabaloo" Board urges that he do so
at once.
The following is a short description of this splendid bill:
, The distinguished American comedian, John Drew, appears for the
first time in Baltimore in his latest
comedy triumphs that are now being
successfully produced at the Empire
Theatre in New York. Mr. Drew
and his company come direct from
New York to Ford's.
In all his career Mr. Drew has
never had a fuller or a finer program than this present double bill.
"The Will" is a new work by the
recently-knighted J. M. Barrie, the
author of "The Little Minister,"
"Peter Pan," and "What Every
Woman Knows." "The Tyranny of
Tears" is a superbly modern comedy
by C. Haddon Chambers. These
exceptional plays will delight all
lovers of the highest dramatic art,
and in the leading roles Mr. Drew's
artistic charm and magnetism have
never been more appealing.
Both plays are exceedingly attractive, and superbly interpreted
by the New York company, including Julian L'Estrange, Mary Boland, Frank Kemble Cooper, Laura
Hope Crews, Herbert Druce, Murray Ross and others. Mr. Drew
is under the management of Charles
Frohman, and both plays are produced under the stage direction of
William Seymour.
Dr. French—What are the three
most used words in this school?
Preshie—I don't know.
Dr. French—Correct; sit down!

During the week of November 9
to 16,the First Presbyterian Church,
Park avenue and Madison street,
commemorates the 150th anniversary of its founding. Services will
be held on November II and 12,
but the service of most interest to
students will be held at three o'clock
Sunday, November 16. At this
service Dr. Robert E. Speer will
speak.
This service is primarily for the
collegiate students of Baltimore. A
group of Johns Hopkins men will
lead the singing, and Dean Griffin
of this University and Dr. Hiram
Woods of the University of Maryland will preside at the service. Dr.
Barr, the minister of the church,
extends through THE NEws-LETTER a personal invitation to every
Hopkins man to attend this service.
Dr. Speer is recognized in the
Orient and throughout the countries
of Europe, as well as in America,
as probably the leader in the modern field of Christian work and endeavor. He received his A.B. at
Princeton, '89, and was a classmate
and comrade of Dr. Barr. He made
at Princeton, it is said, a higher
average than any man since Aaron
Burr, and at the same time played
end on the football team.
It is interesting to note that Dr.
Speer is the fifth layman, not a
minister, to be granted the degree of doctor of divinity by the
University of Edinburgh. The
fourth was Prince Bismarck, the
famous Chancellor of Germany.
Francis L. Patton, D.D., LL.D.,
preceded President Woodrow Wilson as the president of Princeton
University. He is in charge of the
Theological Seminary at Princeton,
and, says Dr. Barr, cis recognized
as one of the keenest minds at work
today in facing the intellectual problems arising in the student world."

Playing like a whirlwind from
start to finish, the Carlisle Indians
overwhelmed Hopkins Saturday by
sheer superiority; the final score
being 61 to o. The Black and Blue
put up a hard fight, but was unable
to withstand the massed charging
of the heavy Indian backs, or to
break down their solid interference.
The red men played like a well oiled
machine, and seemed to be able to
gain whatever they wanted throughout the contest.
Branham played a beautiful game
for.Hopkins; his tackling was sure
and hard, and whenever he received
the ball on the kickoff, he tore like
a streak through the line of oncoming Indians, advancing the ball
remarkably far. Captain Leibensperger was most aggressive. Tippett
and Fulton also did star playing.
The Indians scored first after
about three minutes of play. After
the kickoff, Wilkins9p to Calac,

Hopkins held for one play, but on

Wilkinson kicked off to Bracklin,

up the field to the 20-yard line,

double passes, Calac again carried

Last Thursday Henry E. Corner, '14, was chosen president, and
William A. Baker, '15, secretary, at
the election of Student Council
officers. Some little time was spent
in important discussion.
The unconstitutional election of
"Tom" Troxell as one of the delegates from the junior class was
under consideration.
As Troxell is a member of the
Athletic Board, a circumstance
which precludes his holding a position on the Student Council, the
Council was forced to ask for the
election of another delegate from
the Class of 1915. A new election
will be held by the junior class this
week.
The Student Council called a
meeting of non-fraternity men last
week, in order to hold an election
of the non-fraternity representative
on the Cotillon Board. From among
the three nominees, Baker, Geissel
and Supplee, William A. Baker was
chosen.

G. NI. Janes, Ph.D. '13, is associate in economies at the University
of Washington in Seattle.
F. T. Stockton, Ph.D. 'ii, formerly instructor of economics at the
University of Rochester, is now assistant professor of economics at the
University of Indiana.
R. C. McCabe, A.B. 'ii, who was
at the University of Maryland Law
School last year, is now in New
York with the American Telegraph
and Telephone Company.
Noble Stockett, A.B. 'II, is back
at the University to take up graduate work in political economy.
Stockett taught last year at the Kent
School.
T. W. Glocker, Ph.D. '07, at one
time instructor in economics at
Washington University, is now head
of the Department of Economics
and Sociology at the University of
Tennessee.
Dr. N. R. Whitney, Ph.D. '13,
instructor in economics, will deliver
during 1913-14 a course of weekly
lectures on "Money and Banking"
before the Baltimore Chapter of the
American Institute of Bankers.
A. M. Sakolski, Ph.D. '05, is the
author of a new book: "American
Railroad Economics," published by
McMillan. He is an instructor in
railroad finance at the New York
University School of Commerce?
Accounts and Finance.

year class at the University of
Maryland Law School are Hopkins
men: P. 0. Carter, A.B. '13; 0. K.
Schmied, A.B. '13, who is also
teaching modern languages at the

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 10, 1913.
1914 Hullabaloo.

In considering the amount of
money, time and work required for
the production of the modern classbook, one sometimes feels that the
game is not worth the candle. It
is true that the appeal of the college
annual is limited to a small sphere,
and within that sphere is varying
force; but it is from a no larger
number of persons that the money
and work comes, and for them it is
a very worth while sacrifice. How
many men have wished they had a
record of their years between boy
and man—of all the times of life in
many ways the most definitive and
--reminiscentially interesting. The
class-book is a permanent and artistic memento in word and picture
of the happenings and surroundings of a detached but crowded four
years, which otherw'ise too often
blur in later memory to a phantasmagoria of traditional "college life"
—a far, far cry from the real.
The fact remains that the creation
of a book is a long, hard job—to get
the material, to discover some original way of molding what tends to
assume the most conventional of
forms, to raise the wherewithal. In
this last everyone can help. Especially at Hopkins is it true that the
task cannot be turned over to a
board and forgotten. We have
neither the pull of West Point or
Annapolis, nor the multitudinous
student 1?ody of Harvard or Michigan to make the advertisement-hunt
a primrose path to easy financing.
Nor are our classes large enough
fo.: pocket-digging to produce great
treasure. The "Hullabaloo" needs
and expects a general manifestation
of supporting school-spirit (to use
a much-tortured term legitimately).
If anyone has a peculiar chance to
land an "ad" for the book, do it
without grubbing for commission—
every member of the Board does a
hundred times the work without re-

turn. Give preference to those
whose cards on the basement wall
show their faith in your willingness
to favor "Hullabaloo" advertisers.
When there is a theatre benefit, buy
the best seat you can, and see that
your family and friends go too.
The show selected will reward your
time both in value and interest.
Of course, buy a copy when the
issue of the book appears.
The 1914 "Hullabaloo" either will
do no discredit to the University
(and for that it must at least repay
the purchase price), or it will not
be published—and it is already too
far advanced for apprehension on
that score.

The Annual Disaster.

Every convenience that people
have must be paid for in some way
or other, and it seems that the use
of the University elevator may soon
be paid for by physical injury to
some of the many who patronize it
daily. On Wednesday of last week
the car dropped from the first floor
to the bottom of the shaft—an annual occurrence. It is fortunate that
none of the passengers were hurt,
yet a drop from the third or fourth
floor would undoubtedly result in
a wrecked car and broken bones.
The service on the elevator is admittedly poor, either because the
operator is unskilled, or because the
car does not obey the lever. There
are frequent stops midway between
floors when the elevator has overrun its scheduled station. When
upward bound this results merely
in delay and often in a mad rush
of students down the corridors and
a dash into a lecture-room after the
roll has been taken. But when the
elevator fails to stop on its downward course, the passengers find
their hearts in their throats for fear
of the annual disaster. The "freshmen have no fear," for they may
not ride; but a general boycott of
this invidious elevator might effect its safety more so than does the
city inspector.

Freshmen Athletic Activities.

About forty freshmen, who made
the much coveted 500 in strength
tests, have been put in an advanced
class by Director Kistler. The class
meets twice weekly and has been
divided into four sections under
captains. There will be basket-ball
games and track meets.
Mr. Kistler had the four sections
running through their paces in the
"cage" last Tuesday and there is
evidence of some first-class track
material in the new men.
Mr. Kemper Simpson allowed it
to transpire last week that a young
lady had proposed to him during the
summer. Good luck to her!

The Johns Hopkins Chess Club
will hold its reorganization meeting
next Thursday, November 13, at
P. M. in the chapel. All those
who are interested in chess or wish
to learn the game, particularly
freshmen, are invited to this meeting. Officers will be elected for the
year.
The question of a return match
with the Chess Club of the University of Georgetown will be considered. It will be remembered
that we sent a team to Washington
last spring, consisting of seven
men, and that in a very hotly contested set of games, we came out
the victors by the score of 8 to 6.
It is our turn, now, to challenge
Georgetown to a match in this city,
which will be done as soon as possible. All prospective candidates
for the team are asked to attend
the meeting.

The singers and players of the
University are making good use of
the time before the concert season
opens. The first public performance is scheduled for Thursday, December 4, at Relay, Md. This will
be a sort of preliminary concert, intended more to give the Clubs a
good try-out before the Christmas
trip than to "rake in the coin." It
has not yet been decided what towns
will be inflicted with Hopkins music
during the holidays, but the managers are at work, and an attractive
schedule should be the result. Some
of the older men are suggesting
that the musicians do not try to do
up everything in one or two trips.
Several of the older men know from
experience that a trip of more than
two concerts becomes monotonous,
while if there are six or seven trips
interspersed throughout the year,
everybody can enjoy them more.
The manager of the Clubs is always ready to receive the three-dollar assessment fee.
The Glee Club held its usual three
rehearsals. The tenors are making
fine progress, and the second bassos
are also doing good work. The first
bassos, however, seem a little backward. There are about twenty men
in this "first-base squad," a number
of whom will have to be weeded out
before concert time. The Instrumental Club is, holding its practices
on Saturday mornings at 9.30. This
is done in order to enable the men
from the Medical School to attend.
The "Meds" are sending two mandolins and a pianist as their representatives. Leader Geissel is ready
to welcome any player of mandolin,
guitar, 'cello, and especially violin,
next Saturday morning. The regular meetings of the Clubs may be
found on the Calendar.

Alumnus Suggests Yell.

Harry N. Holmes, Ph.D.'07, who
is now teaching at Earlham College,
'Richmond, Ind., has sent on a yell
which he hopes will be used in the
various games. It is an Earlham
College yell invented by Dr. Holmes,
which he has adapted for Hopkins
use. It goes:
Beat St. John's! Beat St. John's!
Beat 'em! Beat 'em! Beat 'em!
Beat St. John's! Beat St. John's!
Eat 'em up! Eat 'em up! HOPKINS!
In yelling it, the accent comes on
"beat," in all the first three lines
on "John's" in the first and third,
and on "up" in the fourth.
This yell was practiced at the yell
meeting last Wednesday, substituting Carlisle f‘ir St. John's.

Engineering Society Meets.

Professors C. C. Thomas and C. J.
Tilden, heads of two of the engineering departments, were speakers
before the second meeting of the
Johns Hopkins Engineering Society
last Thursday.
Professor Thomas had as a subject "What Is an Engineer," discussing the duties of men in the
profession and their relative value
to the community.
Professor Tilden spoke on "The
Historical Development of Engineering." The speakers were given
a vote of thanks at the conclusion
of the meeting.
